parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There are no studies that have directly evaluated the effects of breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.
[Statement 2]: Systematic searches have not found any studies assessing the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome.
[Statement 3]: Evidence on breeding bats in captivity shows that reproductive success varies, with 6-100% of female bats successfully conceiving and giving birth.
[Statement 4]: The survival rates of captive-born bat pups range from 20-100%.
[Statement 5]: Studies on the reproductive success and survival rates of captive-bred bats do not address the specific challenge of reintroducing the bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome.
[Statement 6]: Rehabilitation studies show that hand-reared orphaned bats have survival rates of 70-90% for at least 4-14 days after release into the wild.
[Statement 7]: There is some evidence of longer-term survival for hand-reared orphaned bats, with some surviving up to nearly four years.
[Statement 8]: The survival data from rehabilitation studies is for rehabilitated bats, not for captive-bred individuals.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the success rate of reintroducing captive-bred bats into areas affected by white-nose syndrome?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Will training arborists to identify potential bat roosts (Action 1981) be more effective than protecting known roost trees during forest operations (Action 1982)?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is no available evidence regarding the effectiveness of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts.
[Statement 2]: There is no available evidence regarding the effectiveness of protecting roost trees during forest operations.
[Statement 3]: No studies have been found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of training arborists and forestry operatives to identify potential bat roosts.
[Statement 4]: No studies have been found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of protecting roost trees during forest operations.
[Statement 5]: The evidence base for training arborists to identify bat roosts and for protecting roost trees during forest operations is currently insufficient to determine which approach would be more effective.
